[Perl] Add array item access (#1953)

* [Perl] Add array item access

This commit adds support to scope the item access of an array.

Examples:
  $array[0][2]
  $dict{'key1'}{'key2'}

This change is required to properly highlight those expressions in
string interpolations. Otherwise the array index would not be part of
the interpolation.

It turned out an array is initialized with the following expression:

  $array = [ item1, item2, ...];

This commit adds the "brackets" contexts with rules to scope the
opening and closing brackets.

Note:

  1. The `groups-nested` is not added everywhere to reduce the risk of
     interfering with HEREDOCs. It is assumed no one decides to define
     a HEREDOC within an array item access expression.
  2. The `groups-nested` was not yet used and contained a therefore
     unrevealed issue, which is fixed as well. It used the wrong match
     patterns. `{` instead of `(`.

[Makefile] Fix highlighting of unbalanced quotations in functions (#1945)

Fixes #1941

Issue Description

  A quotation mark found in the arguments of a function-call causes
  the parser to push into the quoted-string context. The region up to
  the next quotation mark is then scoped as quoted string.

  But make interprets single quotation marks in functions like `subst`
  as ordinary characters.

  The following escapes all quotation marks in $1:

    $(subst ",\", $1)

Solution Proposal

  This commit proposes to just eat escaped quotation marks (\", \')
  or those followed by the arguments separator.

  They are scoped as whatever the parent context scopes the current
  region. The example posted in issue #1941 causes the quotation marks
  to be scoped as `string.unquoted`.

[ShellScript] Control Structure Improvements (#1863)

* [ShellScript] Rename control flow keywords

This commit...

1. renames all control flow keywords to comply with
   https://github.com/sublimehq/Packages/issues/1228

2. renames the "case" contexts to comply with sematics of
   https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/bashref.html

   Each case branch consists of a `pattern` and a `clause`, which is
   executed if the `pattern` matches the `word`.

* [ShellScript] Fix case context stacking

This commit fixes a design issue of the case context, which could probably cause the parser to hit a sanity limit if a file with too many case clauses was loaded.

Instead of chaining each case clause via `set` keyword until `esac` is matched, a common `case-body` context is introduced from which each pattern/command-list pair is pushed. This results in at most two contexts to be pushed to the scope stack no matter how many clauses the case statement contains.

* [ShellScript] Fix keyword boundary lookahead

This commit adds a `keyword_boundary_char` and reuses it in the `keyword_boundary_end` variable.

Notes:

- The `_` is removed as it is part of \w
- The negative lookahead `(?!=)` is merged with `[^\w_-]`
  with the assumption that a keyword is not matched as such
  if followed by a `=` or `-`.
- The `$` is removed because `[^-=\w]` seems sufficient to
  match a word boundary

As a result the new variables can be used for the keywords in the recently refactored `case` statement to harden keyword matching.

* [ShellScript] Rename 'keyword_boundary_end' to 'keyword_break'

Inspired by other syntax definitions such as JavaScript this commit renames the 'keyword_boundary_end' to 'keyword_break'.

This change has no functional effects.

* [ShellScript] Fix wrong indention

This commit fixes a lint issue with an under-indented context list by turning it into an array, which was chosen as the number of contexts and the length of the names is short enough to look well.

* [ShellScript] Address requested review changes

1. The `keyword_break` is turned into a negative lookahead to make
   it work properly at the eof without breaking its function in
   other situations.

   Note: Adding `$` would have broken the syntax definition.

2. The keyword `elif` is scoped with the standardized `elseif`
   sub scope.

3. The keyword `done` is scoped as `... loop.end` as it finalizes
   a for loop. This scope now matches the conditional statements,
   which use `keyword.control.conditional.end` already.

* [ShellScript] Fix 'esac' highlighting in incomplete case statement

This commit fixes an issue which caused the the `esac` keyword not to be matched if the `in` keyword is missing.

During fixing the first issue it turned out the `keyword_break` variable can be used in the `case-end-ahead` context as negative lookaheads work well in positive ones.

* [ShellScript] Highlight stray `esac` as keyword like stray `fi`.

If the leading `case` keyword is missing or incomplete, the finalizing `esac` should be scoped as keyword as well.

This commit does not scope it as illegal as it is not yet implemented for `fi` as well. The syntax does not handle many illegals at all, so this commit does not intend to change that.

* [ShellScript] Fix meta.conditional.case boundaries

This commit ensures to add the meta scope to the `esac` keyword only if it finalizes a valid `case` statement.

* [ShellScript] Fix then keyword_break

This commit applies the {{keyword_break}} lookahead to the `then`
keyword in order to not scope `then-` and friends as such.

1. removing the `meta.post-cmd.shell` which seems to have no

2. removing the initial `set` command which is no longer needed
   due to removing the meta scope
3. removing some once-used variables which seem to create more

4. removing capture groups to improve parsing performance as ST

at the beginning of a line.

According to http://tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/special-chars.html#NOTREF

`!` not followed by a space => triggers shell history function

This rule is applied to ShellScript now.

The main goal is to introduce a comment style which is independent
from valid XML style comments as those might break otherwise valid
xml code when added in certain places for testing.

Example:

  XML comments are not valid within xml tags. In order to check,
  whether xml tags work perfectly if spanning multiple lines,
  test cases must be added within tags, which would then break them.

This is part of the modularization of the whole syntax definition.

It does not provide any functional changes.

* [XML] Refactor preprocessor context

This commit introduces the following functional changes

1. Accept all lowercase <?xml-foo-bar-baz ... ?> as valid prolog tags.
   The currently available prologs are:

        <?xml ...?>
        <?xml-model ...?>
        <?xml-stylesheet ...?>

   This change was made to keep the syntax definition future proof and
   avoid issues with changes or extensions to the xml specification.

2. Highlight mixed- or uppercase tag names invalid, but handle the rest
   of the prolog tag normally instead of breaking their whole syntax
   highlighting because of the none well-formed tag name.

3. Create a dedicated `preprocessor-end` context to avoid duplication.

4. Add a couple of syntax test cases

* [XML] Refactor generic xml tag context

This commit introduces the following functional changes:

1. Opening and closing tags are handled separately in order to
   a) disallow attributes in closing tags
   b) disallow `/>` in closing tags

2. Highlight invalid `namespace` and `localname` parts more
   precisely to match real worlds xml processor behavior.

   In a tag name like `ns:t:ag` the `ns:` is parsed as valid
   namespace, but the the whole `t:ag` is parsed as none
   well-formed localname.

* [XML] Refactor tag attribute context

This commit introduces the following functional changes:

1. Highlight invalid `namespace` and `localname` parts more
   precisely to match real worlds xml processor behavior.

   In an attribute name like `ns:a:ttr` the `ns:` is parsed as valid
   namespace, but the the whole `a:ttr` is parsed as none
   well-formed localname.

2. Incomplete attribute names like `ns:` are not highlighted illegal
   in order to improve writing experience. It is a valid namespace
   part of an attribute name.

3. Enable attributes to span multiple lines, which is valid xml
   syntax but was not yet handled well by the XML.sublime-syntax

* [XML] Move invalid comments tests

As more complex tests result in invalid highlighting tests
to be part of the normal test cases, the illegal comment tests
are moved to the comments section.

* [XML] Fix broken highlighting after incomplete tags/attributes

The main goal of this commit is to improve user experience while
writing XML documents by not breaking the highlighting of content
which follows incomplete tags or attributes.

It adds an `tag-end-missing-pop` context, which is used to pop off
from a tag even though it is not yet closed, as soon as the next
opening tag punctuation `<` is detected.

As a hint the preceding whitespace before `<` is highlighted as
`invalid.illegal` without breaking the rest of the document.

A couple of test cases are added illustrating the new behavior.

* [XML] Refactor CDATA context

This commit introduces the following functional changes:

1. Scope the `<![CDTATA[` and `]]>` as xml tag instead of string.
2. Only the content of the CDATA is scoped as string.
3. Add some test cases.

* [XML] Refactor DOCTYPE context

This comment introduces the following functional changes:

1. Disallow lower case <!doctype .. > tags as they are not well-formed.
2. More accurate highlighting of DOCTYPE attributes according to DTD specs.
   - highlight PUBLIC and SYSTEM keywords
   - enforce order: root-name, type, content
3. Rename all dtd contexts to start with "dtd-"
4. Introduce an `dtd-end` context to reduce duplicated
   `punctuation.definition.tag.end` definitions
5. Add some test cases

Note:

  In order to make test cases work it is required to comment in
  the `prototype:` context!

  There is no simpler way to create test case comments which do not interfere
  with the syntax itself - especially with tags spanning multiple lines.

* [XML] Rename declaration contexts

This commit renames the declaration contexts to tell the reader they
belong to doctype definitions.

* [XML] Refactor DTD ENTITY definitions

This commit introduces the following functional changes:

1. support multi-line entity definitions
2. qualify entity name
3. be permissive with incomplete definitions/statements
4. follow scope name guidelines
   -> keyword.entity => keyword.declaration.entity
   -> keyword.entitytype => storage.type.external-content
   -> variable.entity => variable.other.entity
5. scope the whole <!ENTITY ... > with `meta.tag.sgml.entity`

1. support multi-line element definitions
2. qualify element name
3. be permissive with incomplete definitions/statements
4. follow scope name guidelines
   -> keyword.element => keyword.declaration.element
   -> variable.element => variable.other.element
5. scope the whole <!ELEMENT ... > with `meta.tag.sgml.element`
6. improve content highlighting
7. add a couple of test cases

* [XML] Refactor DTD ATTLIST definitions

This commit introduces the following functional changes:

1. support multi-line attribute list definitions
2. qualify attribute list name
3. include more keywords
4. be permissive with incomplete definitions/statements
5. follow scope name guidelines

6. scope the whole <!ATTLIST ... > with `meta.tag.sgml.attlist
7. add a couple of test cases

* [XML] Refactor DTD NOTATION definitions

This commit introduces the following functional changes:

1. support multi-line notation definitions
2. qualify notation name
3. include PUBLIC/SYSTEM keywords
4. be permissive with incomplete definitions/statements
5. follow scope name guidelines

6. scope the whole <!NOTATION ... > with `meta.tag.sgml.notation`

This commit adds support for recursive internal subsets in DTDs.

This context is meant to catch all unknown or illegal declarations

[Perl] Fix member function vs. member variable matching (#1911)

* [Perl] Distinguish function/variable class members

Issue #1902 was introduced by commit 8726418 and is triggered by not correctly distinguishing function and variable members of classes or objects.

This commit therefore starts with member matching of classes as a first step to fix issue #1902.

* [Perl] Fix predefined sub-routines

This commit moves the keywords `AUTOLOAD` etc. out of the functions context to the `sub` context as these names describe special sub routines a user can define as callback to be called by perl in certain situations.

This step is not crucial to fix issue #1902, but is found worth doing while investigating for further steps to fix the main issue.

* [Perl] Fix user defined sub-routines

The issue #1902 is triggered by recognizing a member value of an object as member function, while user defined functions were assumed to be called with the same syntax as builtins.

But while arguments of builtin functions like `print`, `say`, etc. don't need to be surrounded by parentheses, the ones of user defined sub routines must be.

Examples:

  Valid builtin function call:

    print <Hello World>

  Valid user defined sub routine call:

    sub myprint(@arg) { print @arg; }

    myprint(<Hello World>);

This commit makes sure to match a token as user defined function call only if the identifier is followed by parentheses and adds `meta.function-call` scopes as the parentheses make it easy to find the arguments boundaries.

It does not add `meta.function-call` scopes to builtin function calls. Due to some limitations with regards of pushing into contexts which are required to handle HEREDOCS correctly it is not possible to find the end of an argument list reliably.

* [Perl] Distinguish function/variable object members

This commit is the final step to fix issue #1902.

It changes the `->` token from `keyword.operator` to `keyword.accessor` and introduces distinguishing object variable and function members, because the most recent commit caused a token like `->value` to not be scoped at all anymore.

The Perl syntax now scopes `->value` as `variable.other.member`  and `->func()` as `variable.function.member` as it was introduced for class members a couple of commits before.

[PHP] Add highlight support for phpdoc tag source

The "source" tag can be used to communicate the implementation of
Structural Elements by presenting their source code, or more typically -
portions of it.

If specified, the starting line MUST be a positive integer. Counting
starts at the line where the Structural Element's body started (i.e. the
line with the opening brace). This line number MAY optionally be
followed by another positive integer, specifying the number of lines to
present from the starting line onwards. If omitted, the Structural
Element's source is presented from the starting line, to its end (i.e.
the line with the closing brace).

If no starting line is specified, the Structural Element's source is
presented in its entirety. If no starting line is specified, the
Structural Element's source is presented in its entirety.

Ref: https://docs.phpdoc.org/references/phpdoc/tags/source.html

[PHP] Add highlight support for phpdoc tag property

The "property" tag is used in the situation where a class contains the
`__get()` and `__set()` magic methods and allows for specific names.

An example of this is a child class whose parent has a `__get()`. The
child knows which properties need to be present but relies on the parent
class to use the `__get()` method to provide it. In this situation, the
child class would have a "property" tag for each magic property. The
"property" tags MUST NOT be used in a PHPDoc that is not associated with
a class or interface.

Ref: https://docs.phpdoc.org/references/phpdoc/tags/property.html

[PHP] Add highlight support for phpdoc tag method

The "method" tag is used in situation where a class contains the
`__call()` magic method and defines some definite uses.

An example of this is a child class whose parent has a `__call()` to
have dynamic getters or setters for predefined properties. The child
knows which getters and setters need to be present but relies on the
parent class to use the `__call()` method to provide it. In this
situation, the child class would have a "method" tag for each magic
setter or getter method.

The "method" tag allows the author to communicate the type of the
arguments and return value by including those types in the signature.
When the intended method does not have a return value then the return
type MAY be omitted; in which case `void` is implied. The "method" tags
MUST NOT be used in a PHPDoc that is not associated with a class or
interface.

Ref: https://docs.phpdoc.org/references/phpdoc/tags/method.html

[PHP] Add highlight support for phpdoc tag ignore

The "ignore" tag tells phpDocumentor that the Structural Elements
associated with the tag are not to be processed. An example of use might
be to prevent duplicate documenting of conditional constants. It is
RECOMMENDED (but not required) to provide an additional description
stating why the associated element is to be ignored.

Ref: https://docs.phpdoc.org/references/phpdoc/tags/ignore.html

[PHP] Add highlight support for phpdoc tag filesource

The "filesource" tag tells phpDocumentor to include the current file in
the parsing output. As this only applies to the source code of the
entire file MUST this tag be used in the file-level PHPDoc. Any other
location will be ignored. When this tag is included will phpDocumentor
compress the file contents and encode them using Base64 so that it can
be handled by the transformer. Any template that is able to show the
source code can then read the source sub-element in the associated file
element in the Abstract Syntax Tree.

Ref: https://docs.phpdoc.org/references/phpdoc/tags/filesource.html

[CSS] Use \x{} for all custom_element_chars

Some regex engines such as Oniguruma distinguish between `\x..` and
`\x{..}` in that the former matches bytes whereas the latter matches
Unicode code points, see here:

https://github.com/kkos/oniguruma/blob/master/doc/RE#L26

The CSS syntax matches e.g. the U+00B7 character. So for that to work in
Oniguruma, it needs to be written as `\x{B7}`. For readability, this
change uses `\x{00B7}` which is closer to how Unicode characters are
commonly denoted.

[C++] Fix none highlighted preprocessor definitions.

While reading some C++ headers (_cffi_include.h) I recently found some blocks
not being highlighted at all. Everything from the second `__cplusplus` to the
the final `}` keeps unhighlighted.

```C++
#include <Python.h>
#ifdef __cplusplus
extern "C" {
#endif

#ifdef __cplusplus       // THE LAST HIGHLIGHTED LINE
# ifndef _Bool
   typedef bool _Bool;   /* semi-hackish: C++ has no _Bool; bool is builtin */
# endif
#endif

#ifdef __cplusplus
}                        // HIGHLIGHTED AGAIN
#endif
```

With `#ifdef __cplusplus` within an `extern "C" {` block an empty scope is set
to stack causing this issue. This issue is fixed by removing this block at all.

So the `global` and `global-preprocessor` scopes are used within external C blocks
for highlighting.
